title: Unrealised Value
description: The total sum of value estimates of the items in the product backlog.

title: Rate of Inventory Growth
description: The rate at which sellers are adding inventory. Also consider the completeness of those listings because incomplete ones may not add value to your business. Sometimes the diversity of listings should be considered, too, when duplicate or similar listings do not increase the offers from the buyers' point of view.
tags: two-sided market, retail, online, e-commerce, start-up
interpretation: A bigger inventory means that potential buyers' are more likely to find an offering that fits their demand. A growing two-sided needs to increase the offers on it's sites and enhance the effectiveness for users to find the appropriate offer.

title: Buyer or Seller Growth
description: The rate at which you're adding new buyers and sellers, respectively. Can be measured by returning visitors and divided by time.
tags: two-sided market, retail, online, e-commerce, start-up
interpretation: In a growing business it is not only important to track the number of buyers and sellers.

title: Search Effectiveness: Precision
description: Precision is a measure of search effectiveness: what are people searching for and does it match the search results.
tags: retail, search, information retrieval, document management
formula: Fraction of returned results that are relevant to your target group.
interpretation: Precision tells you, how well the search result fits the users' search terms. The lower the precision, the less successful the search. Causes could be an insufficient search algorithm or search inventory that does not contain requested content. One difficulty is to specify 'Relevance'. It could be measured by clicks or downloads.

title: Search Effectiveness: Recall
description: 'Recall' is a measure of search effectiveness: what are people searching for and does it match the search results.
tags: retail, search, information retrieval, document management
interpretation: Recall tells you how well the search feature identifies correct items from the inventory based on the users' search request. One difficulty is to specify 'Relevance'. It could be measured by clicks or downloads.

title: Unique Visitors
description: Unique Visitors (syn. Unique Users) are users of a web site. It shows how many people have visited the site in a specified time frame.
interpretation: Ideally this index counts people visiting a site. The difficult part is uniquely identifying a visitor so that you can remove repeated visits.

title: Returning Visitors
description: Returning Visitors (syn. returning users) are users of a web site. It shows how many of them have visited the site more than once in a specified time frame.
interpretation: The interpretation strongly depends on the type of business and the time period used to calculate this number

title: % Returning Visitors (RVR)
description: Percentage of returning visitors relative to all visitors within measurement period.
formula: $$\frac{\text{# Returning visitors (in given period)}}{\text{# Unique visitors}}$$
interpretation: Basically returning visitors are a sign of loyalty. The interpretation of the exact numbers strongly depends on the type of business and the time period used to calculate used to calculate this ratio.

title: Registered visitors
description: The number of visitors with an active registration on a site.
tags: online, retail, web analytics, design system, research repository
interpretation: Registered visitors could be seen as an indicators of adoption. The number of registrations has the risk of being a vanity metric because a registration does not necessarily active engagement in the long run.

title: Buyers (1+purchase)
description: The number of buyers with at least one purchase in a given time frame.

title: Engaged buyers (search in last d days)
description: Engaged buyers on a platform. An engaged buyer is usually as one having searched for an offering at least once in a certain time period.

title: Engaged buyer/active seller ratio
description: Sometimes the ratio is even limited to actual transactions in a previous time period.
interpretation: An optimal ratio strongly depends on the type of business under observation.

title: Active Sellers
description: Active sellers on a platform. Activity is usually defined by a minimal number of interactions a seller had in a certain time period.

title: Listings
description: Available (active) offerings on a platform.

title: Average listings/seller
description: The average number of offers/listings made by each seller.

title: Visitor to Sales Ratio (conversion rate)
description: How many visitors end up buying. There are several rates that describe important conversions. This rate however is often referred to as THE conversion rate. It's point of conversion is the ultimate goal of most businesses: the sale.
tags: two-sided market, retail, online, e-commerce, conversion, web analytics

title: Engagement Rate
description: The engagement rate is used to measure the level of interaction by followers from content created by a user.
tags: social media, online, e-commerce, design system, operations
interpretation: The engagement rate provides a more accurate representation of content performance than simply looking at absolute measures such as likes, shares, and comments.

title: Bounce Rate
description: The percentage of visitors who enter a site and leave instantly ("bounce") rather than continuing to view other pages within the same site.
tags: online, e-commerce, website, visitor, web analytics
formula: $$\frac{\text{# Single page visits}}{\text{Total visits}} \cdot 100\%$$ or $$\frac{\text{# Page visits shorter n seconds}}{\text{Total visits}} \cdot 100\%$$
interpretation: The effectiveness or performance of an entry page to arouse the interest of visitors. A low bounce rate may be due to unclear entry pages and visitors do not understand the offer of the site. Alternatively, they could have come to the site with wrong expectations raised elsewhere.

title: Task-Completion Rate
description: The Task-Completion Rate quantifies the proportion of people successfully completing tasks. Also referred to as Success Rate.
interpretation: A common target for top tasks is 80%.
formula: $$\frac{\text{# Tasks Completed by Participants}}{\text{Total Tasks Performed}} \cdot 100\%$$

title: Link Rot
description: Link rot describes the phenomenon in the internet that a site references pages that get shut down during in the meantime.

title: Backlog Order Index (BOI)
description: This index helps ordering the product backlog items. Assess each item with this index.
interpretation: The index helps sorting the product backlog. The higher it's value a requirement deserves a higher position in the product backlog.

title: Release Frequency
description: The time needed to satisfy customers' needs with new and competitive features / products. Other names: time to release/update
interpretation: The release frequency should match the users' needs. A high frequency indicates that a vendor has the ability to deliver value fast. When the frequency is high, however, it can overwhelm users.

title: On-Product Index
description: The time developers can work in exactly one project. The more they need to switch tasks between competing projects, the more delays are introduced.
interpretation: The formula assumes that for each product the FTE loses 20%. The index shows how much time an employee can invest in each project if the time is equally assigned to the projects.

title: Installed Version Index
description: The distribution of customers across installed versions.
interpretation: The maintenance of older product versions has a negative impact on the ability to innovate and other important activities. It binds resources that can be used in further developments. It can also be an indicator that users consider the value of new versions lower than the cost of switching.

title: Average Cost per Study Participant
description: The sum of all cost for each participant in the studies. That includes personnel cost, participants' recruiting cost and expense allowance, lab rental, etc.

title: Ratio of Fixed Usability Problems
description: The ratio between the identified usability problems and those that could be fixed. May be measured as percentage between counts or some measure of effort.
interpretation: Finding usability issues is only worth something if you manage to fix those issues. This indicator tells you how well you do. If the value is low, you may want to invest less time in testing and more time in communication the results.

title: Research Study Compliance Rate
description: No-shows in a study are a risk. This indicator measures the performance selecting and handling study participants.

title: Perceived Product Quality (PPQ)
description: Perceived product quality can be defined as the customer's opinion about the subjective quality of a product or service (also the brand itself) with respect to its purpose of use. It can be assessed using validated questionnaires. Examples: the System Usability Scale (SUS) gives a composite measure of the overall usability of a product. The VisAWI shows how users subjectively perceive the aesthetics of a graphical interface. Servqual measures quality in the service sector.
domain: Software development, Research, Social Media & E-business

title: Percentage of Users Who Pay (ARPU)
description: There are some users who simply will not spend money in a service there are others who do (sometimes they spend even a lot of money. These users are often referred to as "whales"). Knowing the difference between the two—and finding ways to make more users purchase things within the application.
interpretation: Is the key to a successfully monetized free mobile application. Treat your paying users as a separate customer base and track their behaviour, churn, and revenue separately from your non-paying ones. Both groups have different needs that need to be addressed specifically.

title: Value of Created Content
description: Value of created content must be assessed in different ways depending on the use case. It can be the number of unique visitors who see it (e.g. sites like Wikipedia), the number of page views that represent ad inventory (e.g. Facebook), or a more sophisticated measurement like affiliate revenues generated by clicks on content users post (e.g. the Pinterest affiliate model).
interpretation: Measure value by cohort or traffic segment. Only if you know which referring sites bring valuable users, you can make informed decisions if and where to invest in visitor acquisition.

title: Content Creation and Interaction
description: The percentage of visitors who interact with content in some way, from creating it to voting on it.
interpretation: Interaction can mean many things and needs to be measured in different ways. On sites like Wikipedia most users only consume content and only few create it. On other sites like Facebook most users do a lot more than just looking at other peoples posts.
tags: user-generated content, blog, comment, internet, engagement

title: Notification Effectiveness
description: Notification effectiveness quantifies the ability to keep pulling users back in to your system through notifications. That is an essential part of sustaining engagement.
formula: $$\frac{\text{# Messages with expected outcome}}{\text{# Messages sent}} \cdot 100\%$$

title: Time to Funding (TTF)
description: How long does it take for customers to get effective access a loan.
interpretation: Certain waiting times in loan application processes are inevitable but waiting on a loan too long can lead to increased abandonments.

title: Usage Index
description: Quantifies how much a product (or single feature) is used.
interpretation: The usage index is important to identify successful products/features from less successful ones. Hence, it is most useful in comparison. A low usage index may help to focus activities to more important products/features or drive more users attention to features they may not be aware of.
domain: Software development, Software-as-a-Service, Internet, Social Media & E-business

title: Top of Mind
description: Top of mind is the percentage of customers who name a target brand, when asked to name the first brand that comes to mind in an unprompted question.
interpretation: Top of mind is a measure of awareness for a brand. Furthermore it indicates that the brand under investigation has an increased saliency compared to other brands.

title: Study Preparation Time
description: The time needed between becoming aware of the need to do a research study and first session of the study.
interpretation: The speed to set up a study can be an important factor for the acceptance of research in an organisation. Reducing it enhances flexibility.

title: Study Lead Time
description: The total time needed to prepare the study, recruit participants, do the field work, analyse the results and present them.
interpretation: The speed to set up a study can be an important factor for the acceptance of research in an organisation. Reducing it enhances flexibility.

title: Live User Contact Rate
description: Ratio of people (who are not researchers like developers, product managers, management, etc.) who observed research session to get a live impression of users' needs, way of thinking, and usability issues.
interpretation: The LUC rate gives you an impression of the progress of the democratisation of research in an organisation. To give a better understanding of the actual reach, people who observe multiple studies are only counted once. This index gives a clearer picture when separated into groups like developers, product managers, management, etc.
formula: $$\frac{\sum_\text{Studies}\text{# Unique observers per study}}{\text{# Potential observers}}$$

title: Framework Competency
description: Represents the organization's commitment and follow-through on the core competencies of a given framework (e.g. SAFe or user-centred design).
formula: The core competencies for the framework under investigation are assessed and aggregated.

title: Flow distribution
description: Comparison of the amount of different types of work (e.g. features, bug) completed over time.
interpretation: Keeping technical debt to a reasonable limit is an important task. However, focusing too much on maintenance and infrastructure limits the ability to innovate. The flow distribution helps balancing out the work over several iterations.
formula: $$\frac{\text{# Backlog items for each type}}{\text{Total backlog items}} \cdot 100\%$$

title: Flow efficiency
description: Measurement of the active compared to the non-active time required to complete tasks. Active times is the time the teams actively work on the task. For example, if your flow efficiency is 20%, then work items spend 80% of the time waiting for review, approval, testing, etc.
interpretation: The higher the flow efficiency the better is the organisation capable of delivering value quickly.

title: Flow load
description: Total work in progress across all stages (similar to Work in Progress, WIP).

title: Flow predictability
description: Indicates of how well teams are able to meet the objectives they committed to.

title: Flow time
description: Total time a feature exists from initial creation to customer delivery (similar to lead time).
interpretation: Flow time is a measure a measure of the efficiency of the complete system needed to complete a process.
formula: Measure total flow time from conception to delivery to the customer. It can also be useful to measure it for single steps of a process, in order to identify opportunities for improvement.

title: Flow velocity
description: Number of items completed in a given time period (similar to Throughput).
interpretation: A higher velocity is an indicator for a higher output. That way you can track if process improvements are effective.

title: App Store Rating
description: The average app rating. The ratings in the stores are relevant in App Store Optimization.
interpretation: Users are more likely to download apps with hundreds and thousands of positive and good reviews in the App Store. Optimise the average rating. Especially respond to negative ones.
tags: download, marketing, satisfaction, user, experience, app store optimization, mobile app

title: App Store Ranking
description: Position in the Top Charts (Free, Paid or Grossing) of an App store.
interpretation: The higher the position of an app in the list, the higher the chance for a conversion.
formula: Each store has its own algorithms. Common factors considered by algorithms are: app name/title, keywords, user ratings and reviews, visual assets, and number of downloads.
tags: download, marketing, app store optimization, mobile app

title: Effective Cost Per Install (eCPI)
description: The total campaign cost divided by the amount of effective installations (i.e., installations as a direct result of an ad click).
interpretation: eCPI is an indicator for the cost-benefit ratio of advertising campaigns for an app.
tags: advertising, download, cost, app store optimization
domain: Marketing, Software development, Social Media & E-business

title: Average Uninstall Rate
description: How often do users uninstall your app (in a given time frame).
interpretation: The uninstall rate is an indicator for retention and loyalty. It does, however, not consider whether the product is used.
tags: adoption, app store optimization, mobile app

title: Monthly Active User (MAU)
description: Monthly Active User is often used by online games, mobile apps and social networking sites. Also useful for design systems and research repositories. MAU is calculated by counting the number of unique users for a 30-day period. Also referred to as App Retention.
tags: loyalty, retention, user, internet, mobile app, design system, research repository

title: Mean Time to Action (MTTA)
description: The mean time it takes a user to perform an action on the installed app. - This should not be confused with a similar KPI from incident management.
interpretation: MTTA is an indicator of the actual adoption of an app. The downloads may be a limited indicator when an app is free. Then it is more important to look at actual use.
formula: $$\sum_{First uses}(Time of use - Time of download)

title: Time to Upgrade
description: The average time difference between the release of an upgrade and the time users upgrade to the new version.
interpretation: Unless installs happen automatically the time to upgrade tells you how eager your users are about a new release. It tells you something about the value they attribute to the new release.
tags: download, engagement, value, adoption, mobile app

title: Views To Installs
description: The number of times a user viewed your app listing before installing it.
interpretation: In general, the lower number of views to install shows that your advertising and app store listing are effective. The app seems to meet the expectations raised by advertising and communicates it clearly.

title: App Permissions Granted
description: The amount of access or permissions that your customers allow via your app.
interpretation: It can be seen as an indicator of trust in relation to the value the app adds for users. It may also an indicator if people use the full extent of your features.

title: Stickiness
description: The proportion of heavy users compared to total users of an app or site.
interpretation: The more people use your service regularly, the higher the value.
tags: loyalty, retention, user, internet, mobile app, design system, research repository
domain: Software development, Software-as-a-Service, Internet, Social Media & E-business

title: Utilisation Frequency
description: How many times do users copy or share content from a site, set bookmarks. For systems with the primary purpose to provide information like design systems or research repositories can track how many times users do not only visit, but actually use the content.
interpretation: There is little interaction for information systems that could be used to measure the engagement of it's users. Copy/Paste can be used to indicate how helpful a system is since this is a clear indication that content seems useful as provided.
tags: engagement, retention, user, internet, intranet, design system, research repository
domain: Software development, Software-as-a-Service, Internet, Social Media & E-business

title: UI Coverage
description: Describes how many patterns or components used in developed systems are listed in a pattern library or design system.
interpretation: Describes the coverage a design system or pattern library provides. The fewer elements a guideline covers, the less useful it is when using it or designing something new. A specific target is hard to recommend but without any further knowledge you may aim at 80% for a start.
domain: Software development, Software-as-a-Service, Internet, Social Media & E-business

title: Knowledge Base Chatter
description: Contributions to and requests about a knowledge base like a design system or research repository
interpretation: The chatter around your knowledge base gives you an indication of adoption and engagement. To get a better understanding this indicator is in relation to the size of the target group (i.e. developers, product owners, etc.).
tags: engagement, adoption, user, intranet, usability, experience, design system, research repository, operations
domain: Software development, Software-as-a-Service, Internet, Social Media & E-business

title: % UI Design Patterns with Evidence
description: How well are UI design patterns in your guideline or design system are supported by research with users and is this documented in the system as a reference.
interpretation: Design work is much more mature when it uses elements that have a proven "track record".The more evidence there is for the patterns used in a design system, the more reliable the UI design decision will be. You need to define 'evidence' to fit your case.
tags: quality, usability, user, experience, design system, operations
domain: Software development, Software-as-a-Service, Internet, Social Media & E-business

title: Adoption Latency of Guideline Releases
description: The time it takes for an organisation's development projects to move to newer releases of a guideline/design system. Product development cannot necessarily instantly switch to a new release. Therefore, it may be necessary to keep several versions alive and monitor the migration of the projects.
interpretation: How fast product development switches to new releases of your guidelines tells you how well accepted the guidelines are and how fast your organisation is capable of optimising the user experience of it's products.
formula: $$Aggregate(Guideline release dates used by products) - \text{Latest release date}$$
tags: quality, usability, user, experience, design system, operations
domain: Software development, Software-as-a-Service, Internet, Social Media & E-business

title: Ratio of Qualified Participants (Q:R)
description: The number of qualified participants (people who fit the criteria of a particular study) who applied, relative to the number of participants requested by the researcher.
interpretation: Is an indicator for the robustness of the recruiting process and how easy it is to access participants (of a particular target group). If the ratio is below 1 you cannot reliably recruit the required study participants.

title: % Completed Sessions
description: Completed sessions are research sessions that were scheduled, held, and finished successfully.
interpretation: Indicates how reliable research can be delivered.

title: Relative Team Support by UX Competence
description: Indicates how much support by UX professionals is provided to development teams.
interpretation: This can be an interesting indicator when establishing UX in larger organisations. Support in numbers does not tell you the impact the discipline of UX really has but it is a necessary condition when establishing UX.
formula: $$\frac{\text{# Supported teams}}{\text{# Project teams}} \cdot 100\%$$ or $$\frac{\text{Total FTE UX support}}{\text{Total project FTE}} \cdot 100\%$$
tags: transformation, quality, usability, experience, research, operations

title: % Teams Using Methods
description: The relative number of teams which are trained in and employ a certain UX tool or method (personas, usability tests, etc.)
interpretation: This stands for the pervasion of a tool set or framework in the organisation.

title: Non-Compliance to Design Codes and Standards
description: Indicates the how well design systems and standards are recognized in the development team that are supposed to implement them.
domain: Social Media & E-business, Software development, Software-as-a-Service, Internet, Online retail

title: Lighthouse Accessibility Score
description: The Lighthouse service of the Chrome web browser analyses web apps and web pages, collecting modern performance metrics and insights on developer best practices. This indicator uses the relative number of accessibility issues.
interpretation: The score varies between 0 and 100.

title: # Design Awards
description: Organisations may strive for design awards when creating or revising products. Design awards are accompanied by extensive marketing activities.
interpretation: The number of awards (e.g. red dot, UX design award, etc.) tells how well the design of the organisation's products pays into marketing.

title: Average Visits Prior to Conversion
description: How many times do users visit your site before they convert?
interpretation: In a statistic of 2021 this indicator was between 4.2 and 2.4 averaged for various B2C industries.
formula: $$\frac{\text{Sum of Pre-conversion visits}}{\text{Total conversions}}$$ with pre-conversion visits being visits by users who ended up converting eventually.
tags: online, e-commerce, website, visitor, web analytics

title: Search Results to Site Exits Ratio
description: This indicators assesses how often users search something and just leave. It is the percentage of unsuccessful search queries.
interpretation: Obviously, users are not satisfied with the search feature and/or it's results.
formula: $$\frac{\text{# Search queries without follow-up action}}{\text{Total searches}}$$ with total searches probably reduced by consecutive searches with modified search parameters.
tags: retail, search, information retrieval, document management
domain: Search, Documents, Knowledge, Social Media & E-business

title: Average Cart Value (ACV)
description: Average money each customer spends on your website. Also known as Average Order Value (AOV)
interpretation: ACV can tell you how much you can spend on getting new customers, tune your price strategy, or compare the success of different marketing channels.

title: Percent UX Invest
description: How much project budget is used for user-centred activities. Ideally this indicator is put in relation to the relevance of UX for the success of a project.
interpretation: Priorities must shift in a maturing organisation that is trying to implement user-centred activities. If this shift is ongoing may be tracked

title: Brand to Non-Brand Traffic
description: Quantifies how much traffic on a site is generated through brand keywords (which is not the brand of the site, of course).
interpretation: Traffic generated through brand keywords gives you an idea of the success of your keyword strategy. The higher this indicator is, less effective your own brand is to bring customers to your site. You depend more on the brands in your stock. It ca also be an indication that only a few pages on a site actually generate traffic.
formula: $$\frac{\text{# Branded search traffic}}{\text{Total search traffic}} \cdot 100\%$$ with traffic usually measured in visits.
tags: search, retail, online, e-commerce, search engine optimization

title: Discounted cumulative gain (DCG)
description: Measures the effectiveness of search results by weighting the relevance of the search result items by their order in which they appear (assuming that more relevant items should appear at the top).
tags: retail, search, information retrieval, document management
interpretation: DCG penalizes highly relevant items that appear lower in the search by reducing the graded relevance value logarithmically proportional to the position of the result. It can be an effective metric to evaluate the ranking quality. However, it does not take irrelevant (but found) items into account or missing relevant ones.

title: Design System Penetration
description: How many products had adopted any given component or design token at least once in their codebase? The penetration is the percentage of projects using a component in the design system. The total penetration can be determined using an average or - preferably - the median.
interpretation: This indicator tells something about the value of the components maintained in the design system. It makes more sense to offer components that are used by many projects rather than few. Isolated components are dead weight. Optimize your design system to support mostly requirements shared by as many projects as possible. This indicator quantifies shared components but does not include missed opportunities.
domain: Software development, Software-as-a-Service, Internet, Social Media & E-business

title: Design System Development Savings
description: The design relative to projected cost of individual component development related to total cost of ownership (of the design system).
interpretation: This indicator assess a part of the value of the design system. It counts development and maintenance cot. It excludes the value created by the enhanced consistency between products and brand compliance.
formula: $$\frac{\sum_i (\text{Cost of development & maintenance component i} \cdot \text{# projects using component i})} {TCO}$$ with TCO being the total cost of ownership.

title: Cumulative Dark Figure
description: Estimates the percentage of usability defects that may have been missed across a series of usability tests. This number helps adjusting the cost-benefit ratio of routine usability testing.
interpretation: The dark figure indicates the amount of usability defects deployed to the customers.
formula: See Sauro & Lewis (2012) 'Quantifying the User Experience: Practical Statistics for User Research'

title: Lostness
description: Measures the degree of disorientation in an hypertext environment.
interpretation: The measure compares what users do (how many screens they visit) relative to the most efficient path they could take through a system. Roughly, a measure greater or equal to 0.5 can be considered an indication of being lost; a value below 0.4 indicates safe navigation; and a value between 0.4 and 0.5 is indeterminate. When using the lostness measure it is important to distinguish erratic searching behaviour from exploration.
formula: $$\sqrt{\left(\frac{U}{T}-1\right)^2 + \left(\frac{R}{U}-1\right)^2}$$ with U=Unique Pages Visited, T=Total Pages Visited, and R=Minimum Number of Pages Required to Complete Task
tags: ui design, online, e-commerce, usability, experience
